awd_titl_txt: Structure Dependence in the Oxygen Reduction Reaction Electrocatalyzed by Well-Defined Graphene Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
The project investigates the detailed design of nitrogen-doped graphene nanostructures (known as graphene quantum dots, or GQDs) for their potential use as low-cost replacements for platinum-based electrodes in fuel cells.  The study will provide basic understanding of how the structures of carbon materials determine their roles as catalysts for the important oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cell applications.  More broadly, the work will provide design guidance for improved carbon catalysts, thereby leading to renewable uses of carbon materials for environment- and energy-related applications, while providing a diverse range of educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.  

As one of the few well-defined carbon nanostructures ever made, the GQDs offer unique opportunities for studying the structure dependence in carbon catalysis, without the complexity of conventionally-prepared graphitic carbon catalysts. Specifically, the aim is to investigate how heteroatom dopants and sizes of the GQDs affect the ORR activities. Tightly-controlled solution chemistry will be used to prepare GQDs of various sizes which will be selectively functionalized with N- or O-containing species.  In this way, electrocehemical phenomena associated with both the functionalization and edge structures of the graphenes will be identified and used as a basis for testing theoretical predictions.  The high solubility of the nanographenes offers a unique opportunity to study their intrinsic properties, especially their oxygen-activating potential and associated electron transfer mechanism, without being affected by aggregation or supporting structures. The interdisciplinary nature of the proposed research will serve as an excellent recruiting and training platform for both graduate and undergraduate students.  Outreach to underrepresented groups will include a summer research experience program with Prairie View A&M University targeting undergraduate students from that historically black university.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The research is to provide fundamental understandings of how incorporation of nitrogen (N) atoms into common carbon materials, such as carbon black, graphite, etc., can turn them into better catalysts for some important chemical reactions, more specifically the activation of oxygen for energy production at ambient temperature (i.e., the oxygen reduction reaction, or ORR). Our approach is to synthesize graphene quantum dots (GQDs) with well-defined structures, i.e., nanostructures of single atomic layer of graphite, as the model systems.  By precisely control the molecular size of the GQDs and the bonding configuration of the N atoms incorporated, followed by experimental and theoretical investigations of their catalytic properties, we can identify the structural features that are the most important in determining the catalytic properties. The long term goal of the research is to apply the knowledge gained to designing more efficient catalysts made of earth-abundant elements.

In the funding period we established the N-doped GQDs as a tunable storage device for two electrons that can be later transferred to molecules such as oxygen for the chemical reactions. The size of the GQDs controls how easy the electrons can be added to the GQDs in general. The nitrogen atoms largely serve as sites to capture protons in the reaction systems, so that the second electron, which is crucial for the reactions, can be readily stored without significant energy cost. These findings were further confirmed by our experiments on CO2 recycling that the N-doped GQDs as an electron storage device can be of general use for other chemical reactions.

Our findings revealed promising new applications for carbon materials in chemical catalysis, which are being continued in our research group for the hydrogen evolution reaction and nitrate reaction. Revelation of the roles the N atoms play in carbon materials may also have implications for environmental effects of the carbon materials and uses of carbon materials in medicine. In addition, through a summer outreach program we have trained a minority undergraduate for energy related projects, contributing to his decision to pursue higher degrees.   


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Liang-Shi Li
